text: I am Niharika and thank you for clicking
on this video but last night I was
watching the movie Forrest Gump would
you remember that movie run Forrest run
well then I thought why not do a lesson
on phrasal verbs with the word to run so
here are some common phrases that you
can use on daily basis so let's
understand them let's see how you can
end up using in your communication so
the first one that I have for you is to
run after now to run after well it means
to chase or to pursue someone or
something okay so like something
happened this morning I ran off to the
bus but an in stop so I tried to chase
it right I was I was almost about to
miss well I kind of missed the bus but
yes I ran off to the bus I tried to
chase the bus but it didn't stop so
that's how you can use this phrasal verb
well another example for you well the
cops ran after the thieves okay so
basically they were trying to chase the
thieves
okay the next phrasal verb with the verb
run is runaround
now remember we have always learned that
phrasal verbs have different meanings
so like the phrasal verb runaround also
has two different meanings the first one
is you know how kids run around in an
area like you will always see kids
running around the mall or running
around the store running around the park
okay so they're just kind of playing and
running around the area
okay so that's running around like the
kids run around the neighborhood okay
that's how you can use this phrase but
then another meaning is when you are
very busy doing lots of things okay
something that you're very busy with
like I spent all morning running around
trying to find the right things for the
party okay so this means I had a party
and I was busy finding a lot of stuff so
I was doing a lot of things so that's
how I would use this word phrasal verb
okay so I was running around trying to
find different things for the party okay
the next one I have here is run into now
run into it means when you bump into
something okay
or when you meet someone unexpectedly so
again two meanings when you run into
someone okay it means that you meet
someone unexpectedly okay so like I ran
into a bunch of friends at the bar last
night okay so of course I was probably
not expecting them to see them at the
bar okay but I ran into them last night
at the bar okay so that's how you can
use this when you meet someone
unexpectedly and then the second meaning
to this phrasal verb is when you bump
into something
like last night I was very thirsty okay
so I didn't turn on the lights I just
walked to the kitchen and I bumped into
the wall
so I ran into the wall that's how you
would use this phrasal verb okay so I
was just kind of walking and then
thought I bumped into the wall so which
means I ran into the wall okay then the
next one I have here is run through now
to run through is to have a quick review
okay now for example let me run through
our travel itinerary okay so it means
I'm just having a quick quick review
okay I'm just going to explain you
quickly about our travel plans right so
that's a quick review but another way to
use this phrasal verb is when you are
practicing okay when you are rehearsing
or practicing to a song or to a
performance or for a play okay so then
you again run through the performance
before you appear on the stage okay
so let's run through a performance
quickly okay so that's how you would use
this phrasal verb and then the first one
that I have for you is to run over now
to run over something is to knock down
something okay or to collide okay so to
knock down someone or to knock down
something like last week I almost ran
over a dog on the highway that was so
scary but yes it happened to me so I ran
I almost ran over the dog so basically I
kind of knock down the dog but don't
worry he was safe so that's how you
would use this phrasal verb and when run
over also means to exceed a time or to
exceed or to go beyond time
or beyond limit so like for example the
meeting ran over 30 minutes so basically
it exceeded the timeframe it exceeded
the time limit right so that's also
another way of using this phrasal verb
and then the last one that I have for
you is to run out off now to run out of
is to have none left like we ran out of
beer at the party last night ok or I ran
out of gas this morning so this means I
had no gas left in my car or when I said
I we ran out of beer last night so it
means that we were out of beer we didn't
have any beer left to serve the people
at the party ok so that's how you would
use this phrasal verb so these are the
most common ones so with the verb to run
use them practice them daily and trust
me you will be very confident when you
use it the next time ok I'll be back
